title: Monday, 28th January 2019
bodyHTML:
Si hello
Soundbuy Morning
11:06 am

Okay, let's see if this thing works today.

Markkus morning

.... hm. Looks promising.

So, on Friday, the comment sign-in didn't work.

VV75 morning

Manxish Morning everyone

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Ship's Company!
A. M. Good morning, all.

But it meant you missed all the market moving red hot raw I had lined up for that hour. Dozens of searing exclusives. Possibly as many as a thousand.

red i think it was just an excuse to kick the wknd off early ;)
BE11:09am

Never mind, eh. On we go with Monday.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

The FTSE's flat and there's not an awful lot of news.

BE11:10am

(@red: you'll see in your local newsagent physical evidence that I can't knock off early on a Friday.)

Soundbuy That saved me a bob or two then...... :)
BE11:10am

Story of the day is ......... well, it's a bit weird.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Marks and Spencer has begun exploring a technology tie-up with online supermarket Ocado in a sign that the ailing British retailer could look to grocery deliveries as a way to regain lost ground as it cancels expansion plans and closes stores.

BE11:11am

Oh ............... kay?

BE11:11am

https://www.ft.com...-b329-c7e6ceb5ffdf

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Question one, of course, is "what's a tie up?"

VV75 wasn't the same story floating around 2 years ago?
BE11:11am

Is it with an eye on replacing Waitrose, whose deal with Ocado expires next year of course.

BE11:12am

Or is it simply to sign up M&S as a customer. Chuck em in one of those big empty warehouses.

BornCynic Morning
11:12 am
BE11:12am

Or is the idea here to spin off UK groceries and become a tech pure play.

red that could help. m&s food has always looked good on tin. if makes it easier to buy...might help
nightingale20201 not sure how this works. M&S don't seemingly have enough food/grocery to deliver
BE11:13am

Clearly, option three is the most interesting. It's also the one that's been hypothesised ever since the Kroger deal.

nightingale20201 morning
Grouchmonkey Bonjour
Soundbuy M&S offering rather limited...............
lastman standing Good morning!
A. M. (Re last week's mast discussion -- https://www.ft.com/content/ee88d982-20b7-11e9-b126-46fc3ad87c65sell real-estate, load-up on debt -- what's not to like?)
BE11:14am

It'd make a lot of sense for M&S to take over Ocado to run as an online arm (which has duplicated a lot of the Waitrose supply with its own brands, of course, so the M&S shortage of SKUs wouldn't be that big an issue as it looks initially).

red whats up at the dixons today. filled the december gap and tho well off highs still up strongly
Curious Tesco potentially cutting 15000 & M&S moving to ocado. Shift in groceries market?
11:15 am
BE11:15am

The other two ideas make rather less sense, though there's a question about whether M&S can afford acquisitions.

BE11:16am

Bruno at Bernstein kicks around the less attractive options.

BE11:16am

It always seemed a time warp to us that M&S had no credible home delivery. The article suggested that M&S would be a replacement for Waitrose when the Waitrose deal comes up for renewal. That seems unlikely to us as Waitrose brings material buying volumes on branded products that M&S could not bring. M&S price points are also materially higher than the Waitrose private label ranges. However in our view M&S could be a great UK technology customer to fill the Erith capacity (CFC 4) faster or possibly a launch customer for the immediacy-grocery concept that Ocado is working on. Ocado said they would announce immediacy-grocery this year, which offers typically a narrower range but delivers it 'right now': within 1 or 2 hours; in other words: Amazon Prime Now but with higher service levels and better ranges.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Course, the idea that M&S could replace Waitrose might be more useful to Ocado than the reality.

BE11:19am

Particularly if it's currently in negotiations with Waitrose about kicking the deal beyond 2020.

Mouselet M&S strikes me as more likely to manage a humans-doing-shopping-in-stores model than the giant warehouses of Ocado, and adding extra shopping robots to M&S stores which are already a bit pokey strikes me as less wise than wisdom
BE11:20am

But, really, we're not all that interested in supply line stories when there's a breakup theory to air. Here's Macquarie.

Mouselet (also, good morning capitalists)
11:20 am
BE11:20am

In a more drastic scenario, OCDO could carve out the Retail business and MKS could take a stake in it and become a key customer/owner. However, with balance sheet already at 2.75x leveraged, it is tough to see MKS afford even 50% of OCDO Retail, which we value at £2.3bn. It clearly releases significant value/cash from OCDO’s point of view to let it focus and accelerate the tech path. But OCDO needs to showcase the Retail division’s progress to existing and potential new
customers for some time still. So a deal like this may be unlikely until some of these contracts are implemented and OCDO has other case studies to
demonstrate the successful rollout of its Solutions platform.

chad_john I hold M&S. I'm excited.
Bluesky21 @Mouselet - good point on in-store picking, but I suspect M&S's branch network is not dense enough for this to work
BE11:21am

Merrill note floating around this morning as well, that puts grocery at 310p a share and the technology platform at 710p a share.

chad_john @BE - any sell side from the M&S perspective?
BornCynic Anyone spot that Lloyds is offering 100% mortgages now?
Pharma Isn't the point of Ocado that it avoids in-store picking?
IMP.GLD Ophir?
Mouselet pharma: yes; but does M&S strike you as a place duplicating whose supply chain would be a straightforward act not requiring juggling fifteen flaming wolverines?
BE11:24am

@Chad ..... um, no. What's to say from the M&S side? Possible deal to switch from online laggard to online champion, except they probably can't afford it.

11:24 am
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 293.00, up 3 (+1.03%), High: 297.50, Low: 292.20, Volume: 1.87m
BE11:24am

undefined

BE11:26am

@lastman standing: Vodafone's currently plummeting reverse 0.8%.

chad_john @BE - thanks, though I would have thought one of the sellers would have presented an argument.
Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 138.36, up 1.36 (+0.99%), High: 139.36, Low: 136.58, Volume: 23.89m
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Which we can pin on a Kepler upgrade.

BE11:26am

Saying expect a divi cut, because duh, but buy anyway because it's unlikely to be that bad.

BE11:28am

The key reason for investors to hold this stock is the dividend. In our
initiation report (11 July Make or break), we argued that the combination of higher capex, tough market conditions, M&A leverage and several
spectrum auctions, entailed risk to cash flow and ultimately the dividend;
risks that, in the event of a deal with Liberty, would not be sustainable. On
our estimates, the Liberty deal would stretch the balance sheet to greater than 3.0x net debt/EBITDA, which could jeopardise its credit rating. As a result, we foresee a cut to its dividend to a more sustainable level of EUR0.11 per share. Since our initiation, the shares have come under strong selling pressure and have lost around one-third of their value. The selloff has pushed Vodafone’s dividend yield to almost 10%, signalling market belief in an imminent dividend cut. However, in our view the market reaction to a potential dividend cut is too extreme. Assuming a cut from EUR0.15 to EUR0.11 per share, its yield is still appealing enough in our view; and buying the shares now would leave the opportunity to lock in great yield. Hence, the risk-reward looks attractive, so we upgrade our rating from Reduce to Buy.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Not sure how they arrived at E0.11 because the note doesn't say.

undefined
BE11:28am

Sticking to sellside, who mentioned Dixons earlier?

11:28 am
Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 148.80, up 6.6 (+4.64%), High: 156.00, Low: 144.75, Volume: 1.64m

This is Geoff Ruddell at Morgan Stanley, whose 2019 retail preview's out today.

Excel Developer "Excl: Theresa May has made “quite clear” to Cabinet ministers that she WON’T take Britain out of the EU without a deal – but won’t publicly rule it out yet because it would remove a key bargaining chip:" https://twitter.com/matt_dathan/status/1089656403453714432
chad_john @Excel - And if the EU read that article, they'll know all...
BE11:30am

And as always with Geoff it's clear, straightforward and readable. The gist is that while things are bad, they're only 2012 bad (assuming there's not a no-deal Brexit).

chad_john I've never understood why we demand the govt have these negotiations so transparently.
11:30 am
BE11:31am

And 2012 was a great year for retail investors. Outperforming the FTSE by 24% or thereabouts.

Mouselet has something amusing befallen Petra Diamonds?
Excel Developer Big #Brexit day in UK parliament tomorrow, I perused the Order paper to look over the amendments tabled. Even tweeted a thread about them if anyone is interested. https://twitter.com/excel_developer/status/1089136401453584384
BE11:32am

MOST's house view is a 5% chance of no-deal Brexit, so buy selectively, they say. Though there's still a load of risk about cost inflation and IFRS 16 so don't buy aggressively, they say.

red well dixons has already seen a 30% intra year gain off last years closing levels. clearly someone is selling into todays bounce. note could be a bit late for those looking at dikos
Mouselet ah, 'retail investors' meaning 'people investing in retail stocks' rather than 'as opposed to professional investors'; brief confusing
BE11:33am

On the latter point, if you're going to insist on talking Brexit over there I'm going to insist on talking about capitalising operating leases over here.

Mouselet what poked Big Tobacco -2% today?
11:34 am

Geoff says it's the biggest change he's had to deal with in 20 years and there's very, very little way to guess what'll happen.

Excel Developer though actually the amendments begin on page 27.
Catgotmytongue Anything on IMB/BAT?
BE11:35am

It is not possible to assess lease profiles using externally available data, and none of the companies we cover has yet provided guidance on how it will be impacted. Three of the companies we cover (Next, Halfords and Card Factory) have issued profit guidance for FY 2019/20 but, they have all done so on an ex-IFRS 16 basis and plan to give guidance on the impact that the new accounting standard will have when they report their Preliminary Results for FY 2018/19.
At the moment, therefore, investors have little clarity as to how individual retailers' earnings will be impacted by the new accounting rules. That is likely to change, though this spring when the FY 2018/19 reporting season starts. We suspect, therefore, that IFRS 16 will shortly become a very hot topic.

BE11:36am

Mystery box stuff. Anyway, back to Dixons.

11:36 am

Morgan Stanley turn positive, saying it's 20% cheaper than when it bought Carphone.

11:37 am

Meaning, if you ignore Caphone, it's a splendid bargain.

Dixons Carphone shares have fallen 20%
since the beginning of November, yet
consensus profit forecasts have barely
changed
As a result, the shares are trading on less
than 7x earnings - very close to 30 year lows
We believe this valuation is far too low for
a market leading, sustainable, retail business

'revitalisation' strategy, but the move away

We upgrade to Overweight, increasing our price target to 240p. We are not materially changing our profit forecasts today, but we are increasing our cash flow assumptions, to reflect recent company guidance. Moreover, we are removing the 20% 'visibility discount' we have been applying since the August 2017 profit warning. So we now see scope for the shares to almost double in the next 12-18 months

The report, which scrutinises the role of five individuals, identifies a supplier who allegedly assisted the fraud by submitting fake invoices for refurbishment work. Others are certain members of finance staff who, in emails, discussed whether they should adjust fake ledgers to take account of roadworks outside stores. In one email exchange, they worry about where they will get the cash to pay Paul May, the chief executive, given that the reality of the accounts was so much worse than the fiction.
